comments:
I20031211

1. downloaded sleak SWT memory leak detector plugin from SWT webpage.
2. ran eclipse
3. opened the sleak view and an internal error occured

I thought that since SWT doesn't pre-req org.eclipse.ui or platform that this 
should just work. For fun, I changed its plugin.xml file to contain an import 
to compatibility. But it didn't change anything.

org.osgi.framework.BundleException: Exception in 
org.eclipse.core.internal.compatibility.PluginActivator.start()
at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleContext.startActivator
(BundleContext.java:1206)
at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleContext.start
(BundleContext.java:1110)
at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleHost.startWorker
(BundleHost.java:458)
at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.Bundle.start(Bundle.java:328)
at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.registry.ConfigurationElement.createExecutableExtensi
on(ConfigurationElement.java:133)
at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.registry.ConfigurationElement.createExecutableExtensi
on(ConfigurationElement.java:125)
at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.registry.ConfigurationElement.createExecutableExtensi
on(ConfigurationElement.java:114)

This specific problem has not been reproduceable either by Jean-Michel or me.

However I found an interesting problem where, if eclipse is started, closed, a 
plugin is dropped in the plugins folder, then eclipse is restarted. The newly 
installed plugin has a bogus LongID.

I checked in a fix. Thomas, please verify.

I reviewed the fix and it fixes the problem.  The problem was that the default 
adaptor made an assumption that a bundle directory would get created for each 
bundle installed so the call to getNextID() would check to see if the bundle 
id directory existed; if it did then it would move on to the next bundle id.  
The eclipse adaptor does not make this assumption so we need to properly store 
the real next ID in the metadata for the framework.
